newsitem.title: JAPAN: JAPAN POWER FIRMS BURN 13.6 PCT LESS OIL IN JULY.
newsitem.headline: JAPAN POWER FIRMS BURN 13.6 PCT LESS OIL IN JULY.

text.p: Japan's 10 electric power firms consumed a combined 2.5 million kl of fuel oil and crude at their thermal plants in July, down 13.6 percent from the same period a year ago, an industry body said on Thursday.

Ample availability of water for hydroelectric power generation in the month as well as the startup of a nuclear power reactor pushed down operating rates at oil-fired power stations, a spokesman for the Federation of Electric Power Companies said.
In early July, a 1.36 million kilowatt reactor started commercial operations at Tokyo Electric Power Co Inc's Kashiwazaki-Kariwa plant in Niigata, central Japan.
Overall power output by the 10 electric utilities in July grew 1.2 percent from a year ago to 82.2 billion kilowatt hours.
In Japan, operating rates of power plants running on crude oil or fuel oil fluctuate as the supply/demand equation changes.
Nuclear reactors and coal-fired power plants, on the other hand, run at stable operating rates, covering base demand.
